ground_truth_answer: Mosasaurs, like Platecarpus, were marine reptiles that lived during the Cretaceous Period. They were carnivorous animals with flippers, laterally compressed tails, and two rows of teeth in their mouths. Platecarpus specifically had better depth perception and forward-facing eyes compared to other mosasaurs. Like all non-avian dinosaurs, mosasaurs went extinct during the Cretaceous-Paleogene Extinction Event around 66 million years ago, which was likely caused by an asteroid impact. The asteroid strike created a dust cloud that blocked the sun for months or years, preventing plant growth and leading to widespread extinction of over 75% of all living species.
